comment: Worked! Seemed to lock on CM12 "friendly alien" screen forever. Thought I was going to have to wipe the phone, but I waited an hour (figuring it was re-encrypting everything, which apparently it was) and... BOOTED! Worked great. Maybe add a warning that this could happen (unless I missed this). Thank you!

title: Cannot get Superuser access
comment: I tried to run it and allowed root access in privacy guard. It still could not get root access and closed automatically. I'm running a Nexus 6 with CyanogenMod 12.1.
Not sure what exactly is the problem with CM 12.1, but you can installing SuperSU which is known to work.
Once the password changed...   After reboot the OS response was: The password was correct, yet the device could not be decrypted.  Had to wipe everything.

title: Worked Perfectly
comment: This worked as listed. Awesome since now i have two diff passwords. Thanks a lot.

title: It just works
comment: Works without issue on Android 5.0.2.

title: Works great on CM11
comment: This program works perfectly on my Nexus 5 running CyanogenMod 11. Having a strong boot password protects against cold boot / offline attacks, but lets me use a basic PIN on the lockscreen for normal use!

title: Great program, wish I could get it to work on my Moto E 2015
comment: I've tried any manner of order-of-operations to de-couple my Encryption password from my Screen lock PIN on my Moto E 2015 (2nd gen) running Lollipop and I just cannot get it to work. Nothing against the app. I've read Nikolay's page about Android L encryption which seems to say that different Password/PIN combos are possible.  But  after running Cryptfs Password (or using the command-line instruction 'sudo vdc cryptfs changepw "newpassword") I get the following message: "Decryption Unsuccessful.  The password you entered is correct, but unfortunately your data is corrupt.  To resume using your phone, you need to perform a factory reset..."  I guess I will have to wait until CyanogenMod is released for this phone...

title: Does what it says on the tin
comment: This is a great little app for those who want their encryption password to be different from their lock screen password, especially if you use a pin number. It's nice and simple.

title: Works exactly as advertised.
comment: LG (Google) Nexus 5 running Android (Lollipop) 5.0.1.

title: Works with rooted Nexus 5 / Lollipop
comment: For a long time, I used EncPassChanger - it no longer works with Lollipop, and hasn't been updated since 2012.  Found this app, and it works to separate my (strong) encryption-password from my (convenient) unlock-PIN.

title: Awesome!
comment: Works as described. Now the phone encryption password can be as long as you wish. Thanks Nikolay, keep up the good work!

title: lets you decouple the screen lock from the crypto lock on lollipop.
comment: using cm12, is super su still required? i used it initially - but i'm tempted to try without it as uninstalling super su is easier said than done, and i'd prefer to use the built in root managment....
It uses the supolicy binary which is part of SuperSU. It depends on the SELinux policy, but most probably won't work without supolicy (i.e., SuperSU).
Worked perfectly with a nexus 7 on cm12 nightlies with SuperSU

title: Works great, now on Android 5
comment: I've used this app on CyanogenMod 11 (Android 4.4). Unfortunately, the latest version doesn't work on OnePlus One with HW encryption. It says "pw correct, but data corrupted". To answer the author: Sorry, that pw change dialog does not exist on CM12 Nightly 0118 for N4, N7, OPO.

You don't need this app for CM, it has a built-in setting for changing the encryption password. In CM, go to Settings->Security->Encryption->Change password. This changes *only* the disk encryption password.

title: Nexus 4/5.0.1
comment: Ok, I need support.. I change password, and it decrypts in TWRP. But it doesn't from regular boot procedure. Android 5.0.1/Nexus 4
Support email is in the app description. Not sure what the problem is, but the easiest way to fix it is to change the password from TWRP. Alternatively backup, reset and restore.

title: Works as advertised
comment: Tried on Nexus 7 (2013) with android 5.0.1

title: Works on 5.0.1
comment: Successfully worked with Nexus 5 and Nexus 7 (2013), both with 5.0.1

title: flawless on Android 5.0.1
comment: This utility makes it possible to drastically improve the security of your (rooted) Android devices. I was thrilled to see it become available for Lollipop, and can attest that it performs its job beautifully.

title: Simple, and Amazing
comment: Now you have a strong password for your device encryption and a simple password for your daily use. It's ridiculous that Google has the two passwords associated, this fixes it quickly and simply

title: Thanks but is unnecessary
comment: In CM11 you can choose strong password for the encryption device And other PIN password for lock screen..

This app is primarily for rooted devices which do not run a custom ROM like CM. BTW, this feature in CM11 is also relatively new, you need this (or a similar app) to set different passwords on earlier CM versions.

title: Very Useful
comment: This solves a primary weakness with Android encryption: boot unlock and screen unlock need to be the same. Need to be rooted to use this. Be interesting to see if Android L has the same limitations. - Great background info on how Android encryption works, too --

title: Says my device isn't encrypted
comment: But... It is...
Samsung devices use a proprietary encryption mechanism. That is why this app does not work on most Samsung devices.

title: Works perfectly
comment: Many thanks! Works as stated on my Nexus 5 running SlimKat. Now, even if I lose my phone I don't need to worry about my encryption being brute forced. Good work!

title: Doesn't work on Android L Developer Preview
comment: Continually claims current PIN is incorrect when correct PIN is entered.

Android L changes how disk encryption works. The encryption key is protected by hardware and no longer derived from the lockscreen password. That is why this app does not work on L. No easy way to fix because L source code is not available. On the plus side, it might not really be needed, because cracking the encryption password is now much harder

title: perfect
comment: been looking for this for a while. worked great on nexus4 4.4.4 thanks

title: Perfect
comment: Encrypting your phone & using a secure password is great but it's such a pain to have to memorize/input that password EVERY single time you want to unlock your phone, especially if your password is dozens of characters long. This app is wonderful for allowing you to easily (meaning a dummy like me can do it) separate your device encryption password from your lock screen password. So, I can now use a somewhat secure device password (entered once per boot) & a much weaker, but convenient, lock screen password

title: Works
comment: I have a Nexus 5 with Cyanogenmod and this works great.

title: Ok
comment: Good

title: Good app
comment: Honestly, this app did not work on my phone because Samsung apparently implemented the encryption a different way but I give this app 5 stars anyway because when I emailed the dev for assistance, he was very quick to respond and was very helpful. He pointed me to another way of changing the encryption password.

title: A life saver.
comment: This app is light and does exactly what it says, fast and easy.  In my case, it also solved a problem I had with CyanogenMod 10.1.3 - after I encrypted my phone on said ROM, it wouldn't mount the internal SD.  But after changing the password with this app, the phone magically started mounting it properly! So, a thousand thanks!

title: Displays password in clear-text
comment: Good app, does exactly what it's supposed to and enforces proper security practices - need to enter the current password, need to enter the new password twice to avoid keying errors.  ...until you press the change password button and it displays the clear-text password in a dialog box.  *face-palm*
If you mistype the new password you'll lose all your data. That dialog is to make sure you know what it is.

title: Awesome
comment: Works great. Nexus 4 KitKat. Now have a decent encryption password to turn device on, and a nice and easy pin to use as the day goes by. Regards to dev.

title: Outstanding
comment: You made a complicated program that makes it easy to make a simple change.  Thank you Nikolay :-)

title: Works wonderfully
comment: Worked great on my Galaxy Nexus, nexus 4, and my Nexus 7 (all running Cyanogenmod 10.2 nightlies).

title: Simple and useful
comment: Does what it promises

title: Wont work for me
comment: Says "current encrytpion password I'd incorrect" I'm typing in the right password.  Samsung galaxy victory 4.1.2.                Fast reply from the developer! 5 stars thanks!!
Samsung have changed the default implementation, so this app does not work on Samsung phones. You can still change the password via the shell though, see other comments.

title: Perfect
comment: Nexus 4 - just works

title: New update
comment: Got it
The app works fine with CM 10.1 but most Samsung phones are not supported. Please file issues at Github along with relevant logcat and getprop output.
Worked like a charm. Nexus 4.

title: Works!
comment: Kind of silly that there is no option for changing your password in stock. This app worked great. Can't brute force me now!

title: great app
comment: fixes a problem i came looking to solve, ++ =) CM 10.1 i9300 (S3)
Does exactly as it says on the tin

title: 6 Stars
comment: Perfect.  Why Google doesn't provide an option for a separate encryption password is outrageous. It defeats the whole purpose of encryption in the first place.

title: Bam!
comment: Does what it says, and does it well. Glad to see a dev provide a turnkey solution to an obvious (though understandable) security issue! Brute force me now, hacker thieves!

title: Perfect
comment: Works without a hitch on Nexus 4, running 4.2.2. Oddly, I wasn't able to use the shell command to change this, so this was pretty helpful.

title: Works
comment: Just as stated.
David

title: HELP!
comment: App doesn't work!!! Keeps saying old encryption password is incorrect even though it is correct. Tried with other apps: same effect. I'm on Samsung Galaxy S II 4.0.4, rooted with supersu and checked with root checker.

title: Simple and useful
comment: Fills in an obvious deficiency of android, the author is very responsive and helpful, and it's opensource. What else would I want?
Epic 4g CM10 PA 2.23

title: Works great, with a very responsive dev!
comment: Edit #3: It looks like the developer updated the app to 1.2, which fixes the problems I was having below- updated within a day, no less! I haven't had a chance to test it out, but fast response time like that deserves five stars.  Edit #2: I was finally able to successfully change my password. Going on a hunch, it looks like this app doesn't work well with passwords with special characters in them. Originally I was trying to change the decryption password to one that contained the sequence "$$" in it. After changing it, on each reboot, it would not accept the password to decrypt the device. After another restore from a backup, I just attempted to change it to a password that was strictly alphanumeric with no special characters, and this time it decrypted the device fine upon reboot. Upping my rating to four stars as a result- it works, but beware if you use special characters!

title: Great app!
comment: Works just as advertised. If you're hesitant be sure to read up on the blog posts in the description. Pretty interesting to read up on anyway.

title: Outstanding
comment: At a risk of being somewhat paranoid about personal security, I change up my passwords quite often.  Unfortunately when Google released the ability to encrypt devices, they made it so that it's irreversible.  Thankfully this app plus a little root love lets me change my password whenever I need to.

title: Brilliant
comment: Thanks for the utility.
